line: Vehicle Owners Show Willingness to Spend on Automotive Infotainment Features
label: heading

line: A utonomous Driving Technology Piques Interest of Premium Vehicle Owners
label: paragraph

line: W ESTLAKE VILLAGE, Calif.: 26 April 2012 — Vehicle owners have come to expect additional safety
label: paragraph

line: features and are now turning their attention more to infotainment technologies in their vehicle, according to the
label: paragraph

line: J.D. Power and Associates 2012 U.S. Automotive Emerging Technologies StudySM released today.
label: paragraph

line: T he study measures vehicle owner interest and purchase intent for emerging automotive technologies, both before
label: paragraph

line: and after market price is revealed. The top-five considered technologies—based on vehicle owners who indicate
label: paragraph

line: that they “definitely” or “probably” would purchase in their next vehicle—both pre-price and at market price are:

line: “ While vehicle owners remain very interested in technologies that make their vehicle safer, they are turning their
label: paragraph

line: attention more and more toward features and technologies that allow them to be productive, connected and
label: paragraph

line: entertained while in their vehicles,” said Mike VanNieuwkuyk, executive director of global automotive at J.D.
label: paragraph

line: Power and Associates. “Given the variety of interests from consumers, automakers will be challenged to pursue
label: paragraph

line: technologies that fit their consumer’s interests in order to attract them to their products.”
label: paragraph

line: A utonomous Driving—Polarizing Views on Value
label: paragraph

line: One of the newest, and the most expensive, technologies included in this study is autonomous driving mode—a
label: paragraph

line: feature that allows the vehicle to take control of acceleration, braking and steering, without any human
label: paragraph

line: interaction. While this technology is still being developed and tested, 20 percent of all vehicle owners say they
label: paragraph

line: “definitely would” or “probably would” purchase it in their next vehicle after learning the estimated market price
label: paragraph

line: of $3,000. Prior to learning the price, interest for this technology was at 37 percent.
label: paragraph

line: T he study finds that vehicle owners are nearly as likely to select fully autonomous driving mode as they are to
label: paragraph

line: select semi-autonomous driving technologies such as emergency stop assist ($800), traffic jam assist ($800) or
label: paragraph

line: speed limit assist ($800).
label: paragraph

line: “ Consumers are still learning about how autonomous driving technology could be used in their vehicles,” said
label: paragraph

line: VanNieuwkuyk. “Many owners are skeptical about releasing control of their vehicle and would like to see the
label: paragraph

line: technology proved out before they adopt it.”
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: Vehicle owners with the highest interest in fully autonomous driving at market price are males (25%), those
label: paragraph

line: between the ages of 18 and 37 (30%), and those living in urban areas (30%). The study also finds a high degree
label: paragraph

line: of interest (41%) in fully autonomous driving among vehicle owners who expressed interest in the automatic
label: paragraph

line: parallel parking feature, further illustrating similar interest in both semi-autonomous and fully autonomous
label: paragraph

line: driving modes.
label: paragraph

line: I nterest in autonomous driving mode differs among premium and non-premium vehicle owners. After learning the
label: paragraph

line: price, interest in the feature is at 18 percent among non-premium vehicle owners and at 31 percent among
label: paragraph

line: premium owners.
label: paragraph

line: R esearch conducted1 by J.D. Power’s Consumer Insight and Strategy Group to track social media activity
label: paragraph

line: regarding autonomous driving finds that online sentiment is generally positive. While some vehicle owners
label: paragraph

line: perceive the benefit of autonomous driving as taking the control away from careless, distracted drivers, others see
label: paragraph

line: it as an opportunity to be free and to enjoy the time while traveling. However, auto enthusiasts see autonomous
label: paragraph

line: driving as the loss of status and would not want to give up the pleasure of driving.
label: paragraph

line: O ther social media research findings include:
label: paragraph

line: Many drivers believe that autonomous driving is an emerging trend, but is still far off in daily use
label: paragraph

line: primarily due to legal barriers and real-life implementation hurdles.
label: paragraph

line: Drivers would want the option for autonomy during times of “boring” driving, such as commuting to and
label: paragraph

line: from work, highway driving, going to the store or finding a parking space, but want to take control for
label: paragraph

line: pleasure driving or manual maneuvering.
label: paragraph

line: Given consumer expectation that an autonomous vehicle will cost more upfront and also to maintain than
label: paragraph

line: a traditional vehicle, some consumers envision the potential for vehicle-sharing programs with neighbors
label: paragraph

line: or within families as a means to offset these costs.
label: paragraph

line: T he 2012 U.S. Automotive Emerging Technologies Study is based on responses from more than 17,400 vehicle
label: paragraph

line: owners. The study was fielded in March 2012. The study includes 23 primary technologies, each with related
label: paragraph

line: secondary technologies; analyses on device connectivity, navigation, safety and premium sound systems; a key
label: paragraph

line: emerging technologies packaging exercise; an emerging technologies adoption calculator; and expanded
label: paragraph

line: psychographic and lifestyle-driven content.
